title: Mark's Boutonniere Deformity Journey
clinical_history: Mark is a 34-year-old computer engineer who spends most of his day working on the keyboard. About 4 weeks ago, while playing basketball, he had a sudden pain after an opponent's ball pass directly hit his left hand. Since then, he's noticed the ring finger of his left hand is unable to fully straighten at the middle joint, though it overextends at the tip. Despite minor swelling and tenderness, Mark continued to manage tasks albeit with difficulty, especially typing, which is a critical part of his job.

nprs.affected_area: Constant mild to moderate pain at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the ring finger

aggrevating_factors: Long typing sessions, gripping objects, and playing sports
picture: [insert image of a hand highlighting the ring finger with PIP joint flexion and DIP joint hyperextension]
easing_factors: Immobilization with a splint, rest, and occasional use of over-the-counter analgesics
past_history: No prior history of trauma to the left hand or relevant medical conditions
medical_history: No significant medical history, no allergies
personal_history: Single, lives alone, works full-time, enjoys playing basketball on weekends. Has recently started taking piano lessons, which have been affected by the finger issue.
imaging: Plain radiographs revealed no fractures. Soft tissue swelling noted at the PIP joint, with no bony abnormalities.
